Most Popular Coffee Drinks in the United States
5

Americano

Americano

Simply a shot of espresso topped with hot water creating an intense, nutty, and earthy flavor

Dates back from Italy during the 1970s of World War 2 when the American troops in Italy preferably dilute espresso with hot water for a hot drink

Cappuccino

Cappuccino

Prepared with one shot of espresso, steamed milk, and a third or more ratio of milk foam making it a bubbly, sweet, pleasant drink

‘Cappuccino’ was named from its color of espresso mixed with frothed milk matching the color of Capuchin Friars robe, who was a member of the Franciscan orders of monks in 16th century, Italy

Caffe Latte

Caffe Latte

Made with a shot of espresso, steamed milk and topped with half an inch layer of milk froth creating a warm, delicately mellow and sweet flavor

In 1867, ‘Caffe e latte” was coined by William Dean Howells in his essay “Italian Journeys”

In Italian, latte means milk

Macchiato

Macchiato

A shot of espresso with a few drops of steamed milk and a frothy layer of foamed milk generating hints of creamy sweetness and earthy taste

During the 1980s, baristas in Italy likely created this type of drink to distinguish it from plain espresso - because of this, many variations can be found all over the world, personalized to the taste of the drinker

Caffe Mocha

Caffe Mocha

A rich blend of foamy milk, steaming espresso, and chocolate syrup making it the perfect cross between the cappuccino and hot chocolate topped with whipped cream

Creamy-chocolate warmed with earthy flavors of espresso

‘Mocha’ term originated from a Yememni port named, Al Mocha, that was a center of trade and commerce of Yemen’s coffee in the 17th century

Hawaii and California are the only U.S. states that can commercially produce coffee beans due to their warm climate.
According to the National Coffee Association- in the United States-
64% of adults drink coffee daily!
